I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  supports  Viet  Nam’s  ongoing  commitment  to  the 
equitable, effective and sustainable delivery of good-quality secondary education by 2015. During the 
2007 Country Program Confirmation mission, the Government of Viet Nam confirmed its request for 
technical assistance (TA) for preparation of the Secondary Education Sector Development Program 
(SESDP). The TA is included in the Country Strategy and Program 2007–20101 and the resulting loan 
is part of the 2009 lending program. A fact-finding mission to Viet Nam from 4 to 11 October 2007 
reached  understanding  with  the  Government  on  the  impact,  outcome,  outputs,  key  activities, 
implementation arrangements, cost and financing arrangements, and summary terms of references of 
the consultants for the TA. The design and monitoring framework of the TA is in Appendix 1.2
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Country Context. Viet Nam’s economic growth has been remarkable with gross domestic 
product increasing by an average of about 7.5% yearly for the past fifteen years. According to the 
latest household survey data, income poverty incidence fell from 58.1% in 1993 to 19.5% in 2004.3 
The  Millennium  Development  Goals  (MDGs)  and  the  corresponding  customized  Viet  Nam 
Development Goals (VDGs) are showing a strong positive trend. These successes have gradually 
shifted the focus of public services from equitable provision to the better quality of service required by 
an increasingly prosperous population. 
 
3.  The significant progress, however, has been mixed and is not as evident across regions and 
among vulnerable groups including ethnic minorities, girls and women. In 2004, poverty incidence was 
considerably higher in rural areas (26.4%) than in urban areas (13.7%). Ethnic disparity is even more 
striking: 61% of all ethnic minorities were poor comprising 39% of the population living in poverty. The 
social indicators with respect to many of the MDGs and VDGs were worst for the vulnerable groups. 
Thus, the Government is faced with the critical challenge of delivering social services to the most 
disadvantaged groups in parallel with improving the quality and effectiveness of service provision. An 
initial poverty and social analysis is in Appendix 2. 
 
4.  Education Sector Performance. Increased public spending on education has significantly 
expanded schooling: in School Year (SY) 2005 the net enrollment rate (NER) reached 97% for 
primary  education,  90.4%  for  lower  secondary  education  (LSE),  and  63%  for  upper  secondary 
education (USE).4 Having achieved near-universal primary education, the Government has committed 
to universal LSE by 2015. As with the poverty incidence, the high national NER for secondary 
education masks a disparity in access and attainment by ethnicity, gender, and household income 
levels. By 2006, only 34 out of 64 provinces had achieved universal LSE. Girls from poor families and 
especially ethnic minorities are most disadvantaged. Mean years of schooling clearly illustrates the 
gender gap: ethnic minority girls complete only 4.5 mean years compared with 8.5 years for Kinh boys. 
 
5.  Secondary Education Sector Master Plans. In 2005, the Ministry of Education and Training 
(MOET) developed the Secondary Education Sector Master Plan (SESMP) 2006–20105 with the 
assistance of ADB, the United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO), 
the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF) and Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA). 
The SESMP 2006–2010 was prepared based on result-based performance review in areas of access 
and equity; quality and relevance; and efficiency and sustainability. It set out to: (i) achieve NER of 
90% for LSE by 2010; (ii) improve the learning outcomes; and (iii) strengthen management capacity, 
as key targets. Since the middle of 2007, MOET and ADB have started an interim review of progress 
under SESMP 2006–2010. The assessment has identified three core issues: (i) persistent inequality 
of access to schooling; (ii) weak system and strategies for improving the quality of teaching and

6.  Expanded Opportunities but Persistent Inequality of Access. The unresolved access and 
equity challenges are: (i) rapidly increasing demand for secondary education that cannot be met by 
public  investment  alone  and  requires  promotion  of  non-public  provision,  accompanied  by 
establishment of a quality control and accreditation system; (ii) the need for more financial support in 
the form of scholarships and student loans, since only 1 in 7 needy families have been reached so far; 
and (iii) despite targeted support including provision of dormitories and school feeding programs by 
the Government and ADB, inequality of access persists for families in the lowest income quintile, 
where school age children are major income earners. 
 
7.  The doi-moi (renewal) policy first allowed nonpublic provision of education in 1992. Since then, 
nonpublic schooling has played a significant role in expansion of access to education, particularly 
secondary education. These nonpublic schools take in LSE graduates who either expect better quality 
education than what public schools are able to offer or who are academically less successful at 
entering public schools. The Government has encouraged private secondary education. However, a 
solid  legislative  framework  for  quality  assurance  and  accreditation  is  an  urgent  need  for  these 
nonpublic secondary schools. 
 
8.  The Government intends to widen access for poor students through fee exemptions and 
scholarships. However, the level of support is not enough to ease the financial burden for poor 
families. Student loan can be a sustainable measure to expand schooling, but currently available only 
for professional secondary education and higher education. A strategic policy for public financial 
supports  must  be  developed.  As an  alternative  to  scholarships, conditional cash  transfer (CCT) 
programs, which address the demand side, have been shown in other countries to substantially 
increase the utilization of education services by disadvantaged groups. CCT programs defray the 
opportunity costs of children’s education for poor families; however, they have yet to be introduced in 
Viet Nam. 
 
9.  Weak Systems and Strategies for Quality Improvement. Significant investments have been 
made by the Government and various donors to address the quality and relevance challenges. But 
these investments are mostly pre- and in-service teacher training. Interventions in other critical areas 
such as curriculum revision, establishment of teacher standards and evaluation systems, and more 
effective textbook production and distribution have been limited. 
 
10.  ADB assisted MOET in revising the curriculum for LSE in 2002 and for USE in 2004 to 
improve students’ learning outcomes. However, the concept of “learning outcomes”6 is still not fully 
recognized  in  Viet  Nam  as  consistent  with  the  standard  international  definition  of  educational 
attainments. As a result, the revised curriculum still strongly emphasizes memorized knowledge, 
rather than acquisition of analytical thinking, problem-solving skills, and a desirable attitude to learning 
required for competitive labor market. A system for the constant review of the curriculum content, 
relevance, and application must be established. 
 
11.  MOET  is  keen  to  monitor  students’  learning  outcomes  through  national  graduation 
examinations. A valid and reliable assessment system to monitor the students’ cognitive development 
has yet to be developed. This compounds a problem of inequality of educational attainments: student 
academic performance in disadvantaged areas is considerably lower than that of the national average. 
This also makes it difficult to evaluate the competitiveness and readiness of secondary education 
graduates  for  the  regional  labor  markets.  It  is  necessary  to  develop  a  more  comprehensive 
assessment system of the learning outcomes. 
 
                                                 
6  The University of Warwick (2004) defines “learning outcomes” as (i) subject knowledge; (ii) subject-specific skills; (iii) 
cognitive skill; and (iv) key skills including problem solving, written and oral communication, numeracy, and working in the 
team. OECD Programme for International student Assessment (PISA) assesses (i) mathematical literacy, (ii) problem 
solving, (iii) reading literacy, and (iv) scientific literacy.

3
12.  Teacher standards must be developed and applied as a central component of the teaching 
performance. There are as yet no teacher standards for LSE in Viet Nam. The promotion and reward 
system based on years of service should be replaced with a competitive system based on the merit 
and  capacity  of  teachers.  Such  a  system  will  also  provide  valuable  information  for  planning 
appropriate in-service support. 
 
13.  The  expensive  and  ineffective  textbook  production  and  distribution  is  a  concern  as  well. 
Currently the state-owned publisher has monopolized writing, printing, and distribution of all the 
textbooks. Although the National Education for All Action Plan has established the target of 30% of 
LSE students having access to a full set of free textbooks by 2015, the average price of textbooks in 
Viet  Nam  is  considerably  higher  than  that  for  the  Organisation  for  Economic  Co-operation  and 
Development (OECD) countries, and often not affordable for poor families. There is a need to improve 
effectiveness and sustainability of textbook production. 
 
14.  Lack of Accountability Framework. Limited capacity of education authorities and the lack of 
an  accountability  framework  are  key  obstacles  to  effective  service  delivery.  In  the  context  of 
decentralization  of  responsibility  and  resources,  there  is  an  emerging  need  to  strengthen  the 
institutional capacity of MOET, the provincial departments of education and training (DOETs), the 
district bureaus of education and training (BOETs) and other MOET-affiliated agencies. More strategic 
policy on utilization of information and communication technology (ICT) is needed, particularly for the 
effective management and planning of service delivery. 
 
15.  Fundamental school quality level (FSQL) is one of three quality standards for public schools in 
Viet  Nam:  the  other  two  are  national  standard  and  international  standard.  FSQL  guarantees  a 
minimum level of service delivery, and is applied mostly to poor schools. FSQL for LSE has been 
developed under an ongoing ADB-financed project. With the expansion of USE in the rural areas, 
where quality control poses a greater challenge for USE than for LSE, FSQL must also be established 
for USE. 
 
16.  Experience  of  ADB. ADB has been working closely with other development partners in 
leading the secondary education sub-sector. By supporting the Government with the development of 
the SESMP 2006–2010, in collaboration with other donors, ADB has developed a strong partnership 
with UNESCO, UNICEF, and JICA. Close collaboration has also been maintained with the World 
Bank  which  is  the  lead  agency  in  the  primary  and  tertiary  education  sub-sectors  to  ensure  a 
coordinated approach across the education sector. ADB has a current project portfolio of about $150 
million including four ongoing loan projects, a Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction (JFPR) grant, and 
$110  million  of  projects  in  the  pipeline  until  2010.7  ADB’s  ongoing  investment  projects  have 
contributed greatly to improving general coverage of access to schooling and the quality of teacher 
training. However, to deal with the foregoing unresolved challenges, a strategic secondary education 
sector development program needs to be developed. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
17.  The impact of the TA is improved learning outcomes in Viet Nam which are the result of 
strategically planned and managed secondary education. Its outcome will be a mutually agreed

design  for  a  sector  development  program  (SDP)  comprising  a  policy  reform  program  and  an 
investment project that aims to deliver equitable and good quality secondary education by 2015. 
 
18.  Proposed Policy Reform Agenda. The SESDP will address these key policy reforms: (i) a 
regulatory  framework  for  private  secondary  education  and  a  new  policy  framework  for  financial 
supports for students including scholarships, student loans, and CCT; (ii) strengthening the quality 
assurance through development of LSE teacher standards and application of the standards for LSE 
and USE, reforms in the national examination system, textbook production, and review and revision of 
the curriculum; and (iii) strengthening the accountability framework including development of the 
human resource management system for teachers, strategic policy on ICT in education, and FSQL for 
USE. The SESDP policy reform program will be consistent with the key policy targets of the new 
SESMP 2010–2015. 
 
19.  Proposed  Investment  Project. To support the implementation of the policy reforms, the 
following potential investments are proposed for the linked investment project: (i) the establishment of 
an  independent  agency  to  accredit  nonpublic  secondary  schools;  (ii)  the  provision  of  funds  for 
scholarships and student loans; (iii) a pilot study on CCT for selected disadvantaged groups; (iv) 
capacity building for the new examination system to support assessment reform; (v) the provision of 
training for more effective textbooks production; and (vi) provision of management training for (a) the 
development of LSE teacher standards and the effective application of teacher standards for LSE and 
USE; (b) the new human resource management system for teachers and education administrators; (c) 
the use of ICT in education planning and management; and (d) the development of FSQL for USE. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
20.  Outputs and Key Activities. The TA outputs will be a design of an SDP including draft 
government policy reform actions and a feasibility study of the investment project agreed to by the 
Government  and  ADB  for  secondary  education.  A  program  design  will  identify  technically  and 
economically feasible policy goals and monitorable actions, along with an accompanying investment 
component that will support the implementation of these policies. The TA will develop detailed design 
and strategies for the following: 
 
(i)  pilot initiatives that address the access and equity challenges including: (a) a new 
legislative framework for the quality control of nonpublic secondary schooling, (b) pro-
poor scholarship and students loans, and (c) a pilot CCT proposal; 
(ii)  a program to mitigate quality and relevance challenges including: (a) the systematic 
review and revision of the secondary curriculum, (b) valid and reliable examinations 
and evaluation, (c) teacher standards for merit-based human resource management, 
and (d) effective and sustainable textbook production and distribution; and 
(iii)  an accountability framework for managing the efficiency and sustainability challenges 
including:  (a)  the  assessment  and  development  of  the  institutional  capacity  of 
education  authorities,  (b)  strategic  policy  on  ICT  for  education  quality  and 
management; and (c) the development of FSQL for USE. 
 
21.  Methodologies and Approaches. The TA will (i) analyze key policy measures in the three 
priority  areas—access  and  equity,  quality  and  relevance,  and  efficiency  and  sustainability—and 
identify  areas  where  further  developments  are  planned  and  needed;  (ii)  conduct  extensive 
consultations within the Government and among other stakeholders on the priorities for policy reform 
and capacity development for the monitoring and governance policy implementation and associated 
investments; (iii) provide technical support to key stakeholders in ongoing policy development work; 
and (iv) prepare a policy matrix, an investment proposal, and an implementation plan for possible 
assistance from ADB and other development partners including UNESCO, UNICEF, the Australian 
Agency for International Development (AusAID), and the Korean Export Import Bank, who have 
expressed interest in cofinancing the project. 
 
22.  Assumptions and Risks. The successful implementation of the TA assumes the following: (i) 
MOET continues to give priority to the effective sustainable delivery of quality secondary education; (ii)

5
MOET and local education authorities reach consensus on the proposed policy reforms; (iii) the TA 
implementation unit has qualified staff to carry out the project activities; and (iv) local communities are 
aware of the need for secondary schooling. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
23.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $770,000. ADB will provide $600,000 equivalent on a 
grant basis from the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The remaining 
$170,000 will be contributed by the Government and will include office accommodation, utilities, 
remuneration  and  per  diem  for  counterpart  staff,  local  transportation  for  support  staff,  and 
administration support. The Government has been informed that approval of the TA does not commit 
ADB to finance any ensuing project. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 3. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
24.  Project Management and Quality Assurance. MOET will be the Executing Agency and will 
provide the counterpart support including a qualified TA project manager and project staff acceptable 
to  ADB.  The  Project  Management  Unit  (PMU)  will  be  established  in  MOET  composed  of 
representatives from the relevant departments and institutes of MOET and other concerned agencies. 
DOETs and BOETs will be the implementation agencies for the TA. ADB, UNESCO, UNICEF, AusAID, 
and the Korean Export Import Bank will form the Donor Advisory Group, which will give technical 
advice on the policy reform matrix and investment project to be developed under the TA. 
 
25.  Consulting Services. An international consulting firm in association with national consultants 
will be engaged in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended 
from time to time). The selection and engagement of the international consulting firm will be done 
through quality and cost-based selection (QCBS) using simplified technical proposal. The QCBS 
weighting will follow the standard quality-cost ratio of 80:20. The TA will provide a total 55 person-
months (pm) consulting services (17 international and 38 national pm). Outline terms of reference for 
consultants is in Appendix 4. All-TA financed goods will be procured in line with ADB’s Procurement 
Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time). 
 
26.  Implementation Period and Reporting Requirements. The TA will be implemented in three 
phases over 10 months, tentatively from May 2008 to February 2009. The first phase will be 6.5 
months. At the middle of month 5, the midterm workshop will be organized to discuss and obtain 
consensus on the basic design and scope of the policy reform program and the investment project. A 
tripartite meeting is scheduled in the middle of month 6 based on the draft TA final report/initial draft 
investment report (IR). The second phase will be from the middle of month 6 to middle of month 9 
during TA Implementation. Selected national consultants will help PMU collect additional data, finalize 
cost-table, and incorporate the inter-ministerial comments. In the third phase, the appraisal workshop 
for the TA final report/final draft IR will be organized jointly by the Government and ADB in the middle 
of month 9. The revised IR will be submitted to the Government in month 10. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
27.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the provision 
of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis to the Government 
of Viet Nam for preparing the Secondary Education Sector Development Program, and hereby reports 
this action to the Board.

I.  POVERTY ISSUES 
 
A.    Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy 
1.   Based on the country poverty assessment, the country partnership strategy and the sector analysis describe how 
the project would directly or indirectly contribute to poverty reduction and how it is linked to the poverty reduction strategy 
of the partner country. 
 
The Government of Viet Nam recognizes secondary education as one of the principal mechanisms for economic 
growth and the achievement the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and the Viet Nam Development Goals 
(VDGs). The 5-year Socio-Economic Development Plan 2006–2010 targets universal secondary education as a key 
priority. Special emphasis is placed on reaching ethnic minorities in remote areas for equitable and inclusive 
development. Access to secondary schooling has expanded significantly in recent years, but national averages mask 
significant disparities in enrolments, which are unevenly distributed by ethnic group, gender, and socioeconomic 
status. Detailed poverty analysis conducted under the Lower Secondary Education for the Most Disadvantaged 
Regions Project in 2007 shows that household income is strongly correlated with educational attainment. Ethnic 
minority and particularly girls, remain the most disadvantaged. They have for not benefited from expanding economic 
growth and poverty reduction and risk falling further behind if secondary education remains out of reach. 
B.  Targeting Classification 
1.    Select the targeting classification of the project: 
 
 General Intervention    Individual or Household (TI-H);  Geographic (TI-G);  Non-Income MDGs 
2.    Explain the basis for the targeting classification:  
 
The Government has committed to universal secondary education in support of the country’s social and economic 
development. The Project is aimed at achieving universal lower secondary education as a part of basic education and 
gender parity in basic education (MDGs 2 and 3). 
C.  Poverty Analysis 
  1.  If the project is classified as TI-H, or if it is policy-based, what type of poverty impact analysis is needed?  
 
The PPTA poverty impact analysis will focus on the links between increased access to secondary education and 
poverty reduction, using the most recent household survey data. 
 
2.  What resources are allocated in the PPTA/due diligence? 
 
International and national ethnic minority and gender specialists will be recruited for poverty analysis. 
 
3.    If GI, is there any opportunity for pro-poor design (e.g., social inclusion subcomponents, cross subsidy, pro-poor 
governance, and pro-poor growth)? 
 
The TA will undertake social and poverty analysis particularly to identify target areas for the investment project, and 
for the proposed pilot conditional cash transfer. 
 
II.  SOCIAL DEVELOPMENT ISSUES 
 
A.  Initial Social Analysis 
Based on existing information: 
 
1.    Who are the potential primary beneficiaries of the project? How do the poor and the socially excluded benefit from 
the project?

The primary beneficiaries will be the whole secondary education–eligible cohort, which will have better access to 
secondary schooling and good quality teaching and learning. 
2.    What are the potential needs of beneficiaries in relation to the proposed project? 
 
More strategically planned and managed secondary education provision with improved learning outcomes. 
 
3.    What are the potential constraints in accessing the proposed benefits and services, and how will the Project 
address them? 
 
  Potential constraints and risks are (i) effective sustainable delivery of quality secondary education might not continue 
to be a MOET priority in the education sector; (ii) local education authorities might not be aware of the need for the 
policy reform and capacity development; (iii) the TA implementation unit might not have qualified staff to carry out the 
project activities; (iv) local communities might not become aware of the need for and importance of secondary 
schooling; and (v) key MOET affiliates might not be committed to more effective service delivery of better quality 
educational inputs. 
 
B.  Consultation and Participation 
 
1.   Indicate the potential initial stakeholders. 
 
  Central and local education planners, managers, teachers, and secondary education age cohorts will be the potential 
initial  stakeholders.  Education  planners  and  managers  will  be  involved  in  the  Project  both  as  the 
Executive/Implementing Agencies and beneficiaries of the project activities. 
 
2.  What type of consultation and participation (C&P) is required during the PPTA or project processing (e.g. 
workshops, community mobilization, involvement of nongovernment organizations and community-based 
organizations, etc.)? 
 
Nationwide workshops and consultation meetings with local stakeholders are planned to (i) assess and develop 
the  capacities  of  stakeholders;  and  (ii)  facilitate  their  participation  in  the  design  of  the  Project  through 
identification of the structural problems of education service delivery and the development of the policy reform 
matrix to address these issues.   
 
3.  What level of participation is envisaged for project design? 
 
    Information sharing          Consultation         Collaborative decision making         Empowerment 
 
C.  Gender and Development 
 
1.  What are the key gender issues in the sector/subsector that are likely to be relevant to this project/program? 
 
A gender imbalance in educational attainment still exists. fewer girls than boys are enrolled at all levels of the 
education  system  except  for  professional  secondary  education.  A  small  but  significant  gender  gap  in 
enrollment at both primary education and LSE levels has not improved significantly over the last five years.1 
Mean years of schooling starkly illustrate this gap; on average, girls complete only 5.6 years of schooling as 
compared to 6.8 years for boys. This gap widens dramatically when ethnicity is factored in: Kinh boys achieve 
8.5 mean years of schooling, compared with just 4.5 years for ethnic minority girls. Improved girl-friendly 
school facilities and awareness raising campaign among parents on the benefits of educating their daughters 
will help reduce this imbalance. 
 
2.  Does  the  proposed  project/program  have  the  potential  to  promote  gender  equality  and/or  women’s

    Yes          No    Please explain.
